column1: The Dúnedain of Arnor were one of the two great divisions of the descendants of the Númenóreans in Middle-earth (the other being the Gondorians of the South-kingdom).
The North-kingdom of Arnor had originally held the capital of High King Elendil at Annúminas
column2: and the Dúnedain of that land were ruled for centuries by the descendants of Elendils eldest son Isildur.

column1: The population of Arnor suffered a lot during the War of the Last Alliance and the Disaster of the Gladden Fields; after Isildurs death in
column2: not many Dúnedain or Middle Men of Eriador remained to populate the places built by Elendil.

column1: Arnor was ruled by his direct descendants
column3: his youngest son. Before the end of the first millennium of the Third Age
column4: the land of Arnor fell into dispute between the sons of King Eärendur (King of Arnor)
column5: and the Dúnedain who lived there became divided into three realms: Arthedain
column6: Cardolan and Rhudaur. One by one
column9: and assaults by the witch-realm of Angmar
column10: until at last the Dúnedain of Arnor had become a dwindled and wandering people known as the Rangers of the North. Their ancestry was forgotten and unknown

column2: the line of Isildur was maintained through the Chieftains of the Dúnedain of this people. Aragorn was Isildurs Heir through thirty-nine generations
column3: and it was he who reunited the Realms in Exile after three thousand years of separation.
